column44: My organization is in the midst of a digital transformation. It is evident that our existing talent base lacks the skills to effectively deliver in a more digitally nimble environment, and the rest of our business (sales, operations, HR, etc.) is not aligned with the new ways of working required to achieve full impact of our transformation. Legacy leaders and employees are primarily focused on an uncertain economic environment, which drives risk averse behaviors that limit our ability to adapt and grow.
column45: Our organization is focused on two main gaps: upskilling our teams via hiring (primarily externally) and increasing communication with leaders across the enterprise to reduce resistance to change.

Ideally, a consulting firm would be engaged long term, knowing the culture of the organization and its key players. In a large organization with frequent turnover at the C-suite and front line levels, long term direction is a challenge. Direction to the parent company about the frequent scope changes in the subsidiary may help to balance out work and allow for achievement and growth.  It would be nice for a consult to be confident enough to disagree with the CEO and point out challenges/errors, etc. and develop a viable solution.

column10: One of the biggest challenges I face as a Board member is maintaining the balance between providing strategic oversight and avoiding operational micromanagement. It can also be difficult to ensure all members are aligned on long-term vision while still adapting quickly to changing market conditions.
column44: I feel the most pressure to perform in areas related to financial oversight and strategic growth. There’s a constant expectation to deliver measurable results and ensure sustainable value creation, often under tight timelines and with evolving market dynamics

While we have strong traditional expertise, there’s a growing need to enhance our ability to leverage data for strategic decision-making and to adopt emerging technologies that drive efficiency and innovation.
column46: Typically, the initial research is conducted by a combination of our internal HR or strategy team, depending on the focus of the engagement. They gather information on the firm’s expertise, track record, client references, and cultural fit. This is then synthesized and presented to senior leadership or the board, where we evaluate alignment with our strategic priorities before moving forward with deeper conversations or RFPs.
column48: The decision-making group typically includes 4 to 6 key stakeholders. This usually comprises senior HR leadership, the head of strategy or operations, a representative from the executive team, and occasionally a board member, depending on the scale and strategic importance of the engagement. We aim for a balanced group that brings both functional expertise and organizational perspective to the selection process.
column50: I am part of a decision making team
column61: If a consulting partner could help us solve just one thing this year, it would be designing and implementing a future-ready talent strategy that aligns with our long-term business transformation goals. Specifically, we need support in identifying critical skill gaps, building a resilient leadership pipeline, and creating a culture that drives innovation and adaptability across all levels of the organization.
column62: We typically don’t move forward with solutions—even if they’re relevant—when they lack a clear path to execution or don’t account for our unique organizational context. If the proposal feels too generic, overly theoretical, or disconnected from our culture and current capabilities, it raises concerns. Cost without demonstrable ROI, unclear ownership, or misalignment with our strategic priorities are also common deal-breakers.
column63: If I could design the ideal consulting partner from scratch, they’d feel like a true extension of our team—curious, grounded, and genuinely invested in our success. They wouldn’t come in with a pre-packaged playbook, but would take the time to understand who we are, where we’re headed, and what’s getting in our way.
column64: When I’m evaluating potential partners, I trust a mix of real-world experience and trusted relationships the most. Referrals from peers who’ve actually worked with the firm carry a lot of weight—hearing what worked (and what didn’t) in a candid way is invaluable. I also pay close attention to how the firm shows up in our early conversations—are they listening, asking smart questions, and demonstrating real understanding.
column65: We pull from a mix of places, depending on the topic. For big-picture trends and market shifts, we’ll often look at industry reports from firms like McKinsey, Deloitte, or Gartner. For more real-time thinking or emerging ideas, podcasts and LinkedIn posts from credible voices in our space are surprisingly useful.

column44: Number one: achieving profitability in return and equity targets in an industry that has poorly been struggling to be profitable and meet cost a capital returns.    Number two: driving productivity of our people in an environment of low investment and low growth.    Number three: identification of areas across sector geography and product where we do place our Ltd investments to optimise return on resource allocation
column45: Number one: in an environment of limited investment, which means limited hiring, building a pipeline of our own talent is a key foundation of success. Developing the skill set for our cohort of bankers below managing director level to produce homegrown successful productive bankers is a major focus.    Number two: in rapidly advancing environment of technology and generative AI we are looking closely at how we leverage the emerging tool kit to drive significant workflow productivity improvements    Number three: we continue to focus on culture around risk management with our frontline and more poorly at risk costs have been very material to the industry and a key to long-term profitability is reducing these costs
column46: Like most large firms were use a number of consulting firms to help us on specific projects and programs where we lack either the resources or the specialist capabilities to deliver ourselves. There is usually a specific group that is convened to assess which consulting firm should be hired for a given project or program and that group typically includes individuals with relevant capabilities such that they can best assess the preferred firm to use.
column48: It varies depending on the scale of the project or program. For any project with significant scale the group would be high single digits even double digits and the recommendation of that group would then go through at least one if not too further layers of approval if regional, and potentially one or two further layers, if global.
column50: I am part of a decision making team
column61: Corporate cost efficiency.
column62: Typically two main reasons:     First, overload of existing project programs and reliance on the same SMEs within the organisation.      Second, constraints on overall external spend on advisor consulting firms.
column63: In my industry, the business has become so complex and so heavily regulated that much of the work that consultant firms do are often related to topics that are not revenue focused, and not even bottom line focused. This is particularly true when working on regulatory or risk projects or programs. Too often the focus of the consulting firms is to deliver best in class risk and regulatory outcomes but often it seems that the focus on the best commercial outcome is lacking I.e. Balancing incremental costs against regulatory and risk requirements with the goals of long-term profitability.  For example, I see recommendations for goldplating of all regulatory and risk processes agnostic of the true level of economic risk reduction achieved versus the cost required. A consulting firm which never loses focus on the fact that we are a commercial enterprise and advised us on where not to go plate and to take some risk would be refreshing.
column64: Because we have an active dialogue and relationship with most consulting firms we tend to trust our own perspective and experience when evaluating partners.  We clearly look at the experience and previous book of work with other firmsof our partners as evaluate them too.
column65: There are many conferences and forums round table seminars et cetera that our leaders participating from the marquee events for most senior leaders e.g. at Davos or the IMF to Morris Pacific sponsored conferences and events on particular topics. I’ll leave it also on the mailing list of many of the consulting firms and receive a regular Flow of reports emailsand podcasts from these firms.
column66: we have an active corporate communications team and press office that updates us across the various journals and publications that comment on the industry from the financialtimes the Wall Street Journal, Bloomberg, Reuters et cetera as well as more industry specific journals and forums.  As a public company, we are also covered by a number of research analysts, we pay attention to analyst reports too.
column67: as per previous comment, we get a daily synthesis of all of the key coverage on our or related to our firm from our Press office. The provides link through to full articles for further reading. This is red consistently by the senior team.
column68: For a broad synthesis, a highlight constructed email that we can read is definitely preferred and then we can link through for more detail and it doesn’t really matter whether that is a in depth written piece. podcast or video as long as they are concise and do not last too long
column69: Through my phone I have access Bloomberg, Reuters, the major financial journals and newspapers. On a personal level I subscribe to the Economist.

column46: In our company, the HR department is usually responsible for finding and collecting information about consulting companies. Our HR team has dedicated project managers who will evaluate potential consulting companies based on the company's needs.
column48: Typically, our decision-making group consists of about five to seven people. This group includes key members from HR, strategic planning, operations management, and finance. The opinions of representatives from each department are taken into consideration to ensure that we have a full range of perspectives when selecting a consulting company.
column50: I am the primary decision maker
column61: For me, the biggest challenge is how to improve the efficiency of team collaboration and cross-departmental communication. As the company continues to grow, coordination between different departments becomes more and more complicated. If we can ask a consulting company to help us design an effective collaboration model, reduce friction and misunderstandings in communication, and improve overall efficiency, it will be the most worthwhile problem to solve.
column62: Sometimes we decide not to move forward because of concerns about internal organizational acceptance. Although some solutions are a good fit for the company, if it requires a complete change in our existing workflow or organizational structure, employee and management acceptance may become a major challenge.
column63: My ideal consulting firm partner should be a team that can quickly understand our unique needs and have strong execution capabilities. Compared with traditional consulting firms, they are more like a  tactical partner  who helps us implement every detail from start to finish, rather than just proposing a macro strategic framework.
column64: We value the feedback and cases of past clients of consulting companies. Through direct communication with other clients, we can understand their actual experience in cooperating with the company, especially whether the solution really meets the needs and whether the implementation process is smooth, which can help us make more informed decisions.
column65: We often participate in industry forums and professional conferences, especially those focused on the healthcare field. These conferences are not only a great place to learn and gain industry insights, but also allow us to communicate face-to-face with industry-leading experts and peers.
column66: The senior team focuses on McKinsey’s global research reports, particularly their insights on industry trends, economic forecasts, and management change.
column67: We share in-depth articles on medical technology, patient management, and personalized services to help teams understand the latest developments in the industry and think about how to incorporate these innovations into our products.
column68: For some of our leaders, listening to podcasts is their favorite way to quickly absorb the latest insights on industry trends, leadership development, and technological innovations while commuting or in their free time due to their busy work schedules.
column69: The Economist is an international media that our team frequently subscribes to, especially for its coverage of global political economy, technological innovation and market trends.
